Y. M. C. A.
Dr. J. K. Finney of the Medical
School has kindly consented to give
us two talks upon the question of impurity. These talks will be held
Monday and Friday at 5 o'clock, and
we are anxious for a large attendance. Many students are entirely
ignorant of the question of impurity,
while others have incorrect ideas.
Every one should attend these meetings and inform themselves upon
this subject.
Mr. E. C. Mercer, who addressed
us two years ago, will speak at
Ford's Opera House, Sunday afternoon, December 12.
Many students will enjoy hearing
Mr. Mercer again and all who go
will be well repaid. Bible Classes
will meet as usual this week.
To the Editor of The News-Letter,
Johns Hopkins University.
In the first number of this publication there was a little squib attached
to the account of the freshman election which in a sarcastic manner
seemed to reflect on the freshman
class. It was about the election of
the delegate to the Board of Governors of the Athletic Association at
their class meeting. The freshmen
have been misunderstood about this
matter. The sophomores, their old
rivals quickly accused them of deplorable ignorance, but the sophomores showed their own lack of sense
when doing so.
The freshman class has adopted for
itself a doctrine similar to the Monroe Doctrine of the United States. It
is their "Hands Off Policy.' At the
first of last month the "freshies"made
clear their attitude to their would be
hazers and when they elected their
delegate they were merely continuing their "Hands Off Policy." For if
the freshman delegate was elected by
the whole student body, the members
of the other classes would have more
to do with the selection than the
freshmen themselves. But by their
ingenious method of electing their
delegate, the freshmen would have
forced the upperclassmen to ratify
their candidate as no matter whom
the members of the other classes
would have nominated for freshman delegate, all the nominees would
have resigned except the one elected
at the freshman class meeting. The
freshmen therefore think that instead
of being accused .of deplorable ignorance, they should be given credit for
having shown the most foresight of
any class that has ever entered this
institution, as they were the first to
find a way of sending a delegate
elected by themselves to the Board of
Governors of the Athletic Association.

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
I would like to say that the varsity
lacrosse team of the Johns Hopkins
University has by no means the appearance of a losing team. The prospects are, however, nothing to boast
of. Of last year's team, there arc
just five men left: Clary, Stockett,
Klein, Keith, and Schmeisser. The
men who had a good chance of making the team last year have been
working faithfully. One or two
Freshman have also taken an interest
in the game. But as a whole, there
seems to be a scarcity of men out
for the team. We need candidates, and we must have them for
this year's team.
Official lacrosse practice will commence on Monday, December 6, 'o9,
at 4.40 P. M., and will be held daily
in the Cage. Everybody come out
and help to form next spring's team.
G. L. Schmeisser.

THE DANCE
The first dance of the season will
be held Friday evening, December
tenth. These dances are held under
the auspices of the Cotillon Club and
should be supported by every one in
the University. It should not be expected that the members of the club
can see personally every one whom
they think might like to come to the
dance. On the contrary, those desiring to go should come forward
and give their names to some member of the club. It should also be
realized that the committee, no matter how hard it works, cannot make
the dances successful without the patronage of the members of the University, who should regard them as
college activities and treat them as
such.

Y. M. C. A.
Dr. J. K. Finney of the Medical
School has kindly consented to give
us two talks upon the question of impurity. These talks will be held
Monday and Friday at 5 o'clock, and
we are anxious for a large attendance. Many students are entirely
ignorant of the question of impurity,
while others have incorrect ideas.
Every one should attend these meetings and inform themselves upon
this subject.
Mr. E. C. Mercer, who addressed
us two years ago, will speak at
Ford's Opera House, Sunday afternoon, December 12.
Many students will enjoy hearing
Mr. Mercer again and all who go
will be well repaid. Bible Classes
will meet as usual this week.
To the Editor of The News-Letter,
Johns Hopkins University.
In the first number of this publication there was a little squib attached
to the account of the freshman election which in a sarcastic manner
seemed to reflect on the freshman
class. It was about the election of
the delegate to the Board of Governors of the Athletic Association at
their class meeting. The freshmen
have been misunderstood about this
matter. The sophomores, their old
rivals quickly accused them of deplorable ignorance, but the sophomores showed their own lack of sense
when doing so.
The freshman class has adopted for
itself a doctrine similar to the Monroe Doctrine of the United States. It
is their "Hands Off Policy.' At the
first of last month the "freshies"made
clear their attitude to their would be
hazers and when they elected their
delegate they were merely continuing their "Hands Off Policy." For if
the freshman delegate was elected by
the whole student body, the members
of the other classes would have more
to do with the selection than the
freshmen themselves. But by their
ingenious method of electing their
delegate, the freshmen would have
forced the upperclassmen to ratify
their candidate as no matter whom
the members of the other classes
would have nominated for freshman delegate, all the nominees would
have resigned except the one elected
at the freshman class meeting. The
freshmen therefore think that instead
of being accused .of deplorable ignorance, they should be given credit for
having shown the most foresight of
any class that has ever entered this
institution, as they were the first to
find a way of sending a delegate
elected by themselves to the Board of
Governors of the Athletic Association.

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
I would like to say that the varsity
lacrosse team of the Johns Hopkins
University has by no means the appearance of a losing team. The prospects are, however, nothing to boast
of. Of last year's team, there arc
just five men left: Clary, Stockett,
Klein, Keith, and Schmeisser. The
men who had a good chance of making the team last year have been
working faithfully. One or two
Freshman have also taken an interest
in the game. But as a whole, there
seems to be a scarcity of men out
for the team. We need candidates, and we must have them for
this year's team.
Official lacrosse practice will commence on Monday, December 6, 'o9,
at 4.40 P. M., and will be held daily
in the Cage. Everybody come out
and help to form next spring's team.
G. L. Schmeisser.

THE DANCE
The first dance of the season will
be held Friday evening, December
tenth. These dances are held under
the auspices of the Cotillon Club and
should be supported by every one in
the University. It should not be expected that the members of the club
can see personally every one whom
they think might like to come to the
dance. On the contrary, those desiring to go should come forward
and give their names to some member of the club. It should also be
realized that the committee, no matter how hard it works, cannot make
the dances successful without the patronage of the members of the University, who should regard them as
college activities and treat them as
such.
